head.title: The Gift of Life, Even at the End

hedline.hl1: The Gift of Life, Even at the End

abstract.p: Rick Feinstein letter says David A Shaywitz (Sept 19 Op-Ed) is correct in saying that real skill in medicine is not in teaching people how to let go but in descerning who will truly benefit from heroic efforts; recalls good years his father-in-law enjoyed after being saved from near death (S)

block.p: Re ''The Right to Live,'' by David A. Shaywitz (Op-Ed, Sept. 19):

A few years ago, my father-in-law, in his early 80's, was admitted to Mount Sinai Hospital after contracting pneumonia. There, in quick succession, he suffered a heart attack, kidney failure, severe infection and cardiac arrest.
Re ''The Right to Live,'' by David A. Shaywitz (Op-Ed, Sept. 19):

A few years ago, my father-in-law, in his early 80's, was admitted to Mount Sinai Hospital after contracting pneumonia. There, in quick succession, he suffered a heart attack, kidney failure, severe infection and cardiac arrest.
We were counseled by his attending doctor to let everyone know that, before his admission, he was not ''a sick, old man'' but rather a viable human being who enjoyed life.
When he left the hospital two months later, under his own power, it was among the happiest moments of his and our lives.
In the two ensuing years, he golfed, traveled and attended family celebrations. We have never stopped giving thanks.
Dr. Shaywitz is right: the real skill is not in teaching people how to let go but in discerning who will truly benefit from heroic efforts and who won't.
